answers.answer: I've never heard of this (not to say it isn't the case).  However, diabetes can cause peripheral nerve issues . . .
I know that steroids (if you are taking them) messes with the glucose levels.

If the lab tech said something like "insulin resistant."  Most doctors have stopped calling it insulin resistance and they refer to it an "metabolic syndrome."  It has a few diagnostic indicators:  elevated fasting glucose, elevated hemoglobin A1C, waist > 40" in males or >35" in females, decreased levels of HDL, etc.  I don't remember the whole list.It is normally considered "pre-Type 2 Diabetes." and there is quite a bit that can be done with diet, exercise,  weight loss, etc.  As far as I know, there is no causal linkage between MS and Metabolic Syndrome or Type II Diabetes (other than maybe the increased weight and "spread" that can come with decreased mobility, pain, depression that seems to come with MS.)  MS itself would not be a "direct cause" to "metabolic syndrome."Bob
